extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "Example:
```python
import pandas as pd
from scipy import sparse as sc
import numpy as np

np.random.seed(42)
a = np.random.randint(0, 10, size=(200, 5))
a_sp = sc.coo_matrix(a)
a_sp_pd = pd.DataFrame.sparse.from_spmatrix(a_sp)
a_sp_pd.max()
```
Expected output:
```
0    9
1    9
2    9
3    9
4    9
dtype: int64

```

Actual output:
```
Series([], dtype: float64)
```


System info: 
```
  - numpy [required: >=1.17, installed: 1.20.2]
  - scipy [required: >=0.19.1, installed: 1.6.2]
  - pandas [required: >=1.0.0,<=1.1.4, installed: 1.2.4]
```"
    ],
    "title": [
        "BUG: max()/min() don't work on DataFrames  constructed from scipy sparse matrix"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Bug",
            "description": null
        },
        {
            "name": "Sparse",
            "description": "Sparse Data Type"
        },
        {
            "name": "Reduction Operations",
            "description": "sum, mean, min, max, etc."
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

    "body": "file.copy now will ensure ownership of files when using file.copy and there's no way to disable this. If preserve is True.     "id": 549564544,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/15325",
    "body": "Current output from [this example](https://numpy.org/devdocs/f2py/python-usage.html#allocatable-arrays) in the docs:\r\n\r\n```python\r\n>>> import allocarr\r\n>>> print(allocarr.mod.__doc__)\r\n'f'-\r\nfoo()\r\n\r\nWrapper for ``foo``.\r\n\r\n\r\n>>> \r\n```\r\n\r\nExpected output:\r\n\r\n```python\r\n>>> import allocarr \r\n>>> print(allocarr.mod.__doc__)\r\nb - 'f'-array(-1,-1), not allocated\r\nfoo - Function signature:\r\n  foo()\r\n\r\n>>>\r\n```\r\n\r\nf2py output is also incomplete in other situations (see for example #15308 )\r\n\r\n```python\r\n>>> import sys, numpy; print(numpy.__version__, sys.version)\r\n1.19.0.dev0+edb5f56 3.6.7 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Jul  2 2019, 02:18:42) \r\n[GCC 7.3.0]\r\n```\r\n\r\n",

{
    "body": [
        "Current output from [this example](https://numpy.org/devdocs/f2py/python-usage.html#allocatable-arrays) in the docs:

```python
>>> import allocarr
>>> print(allocarr.mod.__doc__)
'f'-
foo()

Wrapper for ``foo``.


>>> 
```

Expected output:

```python
>>> import allocarr 
>>> print(allocarr.mod.__doc__)
b - 'f'-array(-1,-1), not allocated
foo - Function signature:
  foo()

>>>
```

f2py output is also incomplete in other situations (see for example #15308 )

```python
>>> import sys, numpy; print(numpy.__version__, sys.version)
1.19.0.dev0+edb5f56 3.6.7 | packaged by conda-forge | (default, Jul  2 2019, 02:18:42) 
[GCC 7.3.0]
```

"
    ],
    "title": [
        "BUG: f2py does not report names of module data items"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "00 - Bug",
            "description": null
        },
        {
            "name": "component: numpy.f2py",
            "description": null
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

    "body": "### What does this PR do?\r\nIgnore configuration for 'enable_fqdns_grains' for AIX, Solaris and Juniper\r\n\r\n### What issues does this PR fix or reference?\r\nFixes:  #60529\r\n\r\n### Previous Behavior\r\n'enable_fqdns_grains' default value of True was causing issues porting Salt 3003.1 (Seq Fault - Core), fixed with a patch file.\r\n\r\n### New Behavior\r\nIgnore 'enable_fqdns_grains' setting similar to existing Windows and Proxy checks, for AIX, Solaris and Junos (Juniper) where checking for fqdns has or will cause issues, for example: reverse DNS lookup on a Juniper router will be problematic (current native minion ships with setting defaulted to False). This change alieves this.\r\n\r\n### Merge requirements satisfied?\r\n**[NOTICE] Bug fixes or features added to Salt require tests.**\r\n<!-- Please review the [test documentation](https://docs.saltstack.com/en/master/topics/tutorials/writing_tests.html) for details on how to implement tests into Salt's test suite. -->\r\n- [ ] Docs\r\n- [X] Changelog - https://docs.saltstack.com/en/master/topics/development/changelog.html\r\n- [X] Tests written/updated\r\n\r\n### Commits signed with GPG?\r\nYes\r\n\r\nPlease review [Salt's Contributing Guide](https://docs.saltstack.com/en/master/topics/development/contributing.html) for best practices.\r\n\r\nSee GitHub's [page on GPG signing](https://help.github.com/articles/signing-commits-using-gpg/) for more information about signing commits with GPG.\r\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "### What does this PR do?
Ignore configuration for 'enable_fqdns_grains' for AIX, Solaris and Juniper

### What issues does this PR fix or reference?
Fixes:  #60529

### Previous Behavior
'enable_fqdns_grains' default value of True was causing issues porting Salt 3003.1 (Seq Fault - Core), fixed with a patch file.

### New Behavior
Ignore 'enable_fqdns_grains' setting similar to existing Windows and Proxy checks, for AIX, Solaris and Junos (Juniper) where checking for fqdns has or will cause issues, for example: reverse DNS lookup on a Juniper router will be problematic (current native minion ships with setting defaulted to False). This change alieves this.

### Merge requirements satisfied?
**[NOTICE] Bug fixes or features added to Salt require tests.**
<!-- Please review the [test documentation](https://docs.saltstack.com/en/master/topics/tutorials/writing_tests.html) for details on how to implement tests into Salt's test suite. -->
- [ ] Docs
- [X] Changelog - https://docs.saltstack.com/en/master/topics/development/changelog.html
- [X] Tests written/updated

### Commits signed with GPG?
Yes

Please review [Salt's Contributing Guide](https://docs.saltstack.com/en/master/topics/development/contributing.html) for best practices.

See GitHub's [page on GPG signing](https://help.github.com/articles/signing-commits-using-gpg/) for more information about signing commits with GPG.
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "[freeze] Ignore configuration for 'enable_fqdns_grains' for AIX, Solaris and Juniper"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Bug",
            "description": "broken, incorrect, or confusing behavior"
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

    "body": "**Description**
When calling an aync_runner function from salt-api the info dictionary always contains an error which states "Cannot contact returner or no job with this jid" even though the job runs and completes successfully with return data. 

**Setup**
N/A - No specifc setup is required, The runner simply needs to be called via the runner_async client. 

**Steps to Reproduce the behavior**
Calling a runner function using runner_async client from salt-api:

Example payload:

`[{
    "client": "runner_async",
    "arg1": "foo",
    "arg2": "bar"
}]`

**Expected behavior**
The error Key should only be displayed/populated in the event an error occurs or the job truly cannot be found. 

**Screenshots**

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "_Original ticket http://projects.scipy.org/numpy/ticket/1839 on 2011-05-24 by trac user risa2000, assigned to @pierregm._

Using masked array with np.object type makes the rows with that type, which also contain masked values raise an exception.

Slightly modified sample from documentation follows:

```
In [22]: from numpy import ma

In [23]: y = ma.masked_array([(1,'2'), (3, '4')], mask=[(0, 0), (0, 1)], dtype=[('a', int), ('b', np.object)])

In [24]: y[0]
Out[24]: (1, '2')

In [25]: y[1]
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)

f:\Work\python\apps\icao\icao_results.py in <module>()
----> 1
      2
      3
      4
      5

C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\numpy\ma\core.pyc in __getitem__(self, indx)
   2946 #                return mvoid(dout, mask=mask)

   2947                 if flatten_mask(mask).any():
-> 2948                     dout = mvoid(dout, mask=mask)
   2949                 else:
   2950                     return dout

C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\numpy\ma\core.pyc in __new__(self, data, mask, dtype, fill_value)
   5506         dtype = dtype or data.dtype
   5507         _data = ndarray((), dtype=dtype)
-> 5508         _data[()] = data
   5509         _data = _data.view(self)
   5510         if mask is not nomask:

ValueError: Setting void-array with object members using buffer.

In [26]: y
Out[26]:
masked_array(data = [(1, '2') (3, --)],
             mask = [(False, False) (False, True)],
       fill_value = (999999, '?'),
            dtype = [('a', '<i4'), ('b', '|O4')])
```
"
    ],

        "cannot access masked array rows with np.object dtype (Trac #1839)"

    "body": "xref #7795 #13221. Series/Index concat-like op which triggers object-coercion is not well tested. Followings are needed: \n- Refactor `concat` internal to make it consistent / stabled. \n- Add comprehensive tests to cover both Index/Series object-coercion cases \n#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example if possible\n\nFound some problems below:\n\n```\n# NG. though it looks OK, the objects are python built-in (must be Timestamp and Timedelta)\ns = pd.Series([pd.Timestamp('2011-01-01')]).append(pd.Series([pd.Timedelta('1 days')]))\ns\n#0    2011-01-01 00:00:00\n#0         1 day, 0:00:00\n# dtype: object\n\ntype(s.iloc[0]), type(s.iloc[-1])\n# (datetime.datetime, datetime.timedelta)\n```\n\n```\n# NG, the result must be object dtype contaions Timestamp and Timedelta\nidx = pd.DatetimeIndex(['2011-01-01']).append(pd.TimedeltaIndex(['1 days']))\nidx\n# Index([2011-01-01 00:00:00, 86400000000000], dtype='object')\n\ntype(idx[0]), type(idx[-1])\n# (pandas.tslib.Timestamp, int)\n```\n#### Expected Output\n- result must be object dtype containing `Timestamp` and `Timedelta` (not `datetime` and `timedelta`)\n#### output of `pd.show_versions()`\n\n0.18.1\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "xref #7795 #13221. Series/Index concat-like op which triggers object-coercion is not well tested. Followings are needed: 
- Refactor `concat` internal to make it consistent / stabled. 
- Add comprehensive tests to cover both Index/Series object-coercion cases 
#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example if possible

Found some problems below:

```
# NG. though it looks OK, the objects are python built-in (must be Timestamp and Timedelta)
s = pd.Series([pd.Timestamp('2011-01-01')]).append(pd.Series([pd.Timedelta('1 days')]))
s
#0    2011-01-01 00:00:00
#0         1 day, 0:00:00
# dtype: object

type(s.iloc[0]), type(s.iloc[-1])
# (datetime.datetime, datetime.timedelta)
```

```
# NG, the result must be object dtype contaions Timestamp and Timedelta
idx = pd.DatetimeIndex(['2011-01-01']).append(pd.TimedeltaIndex(['1 days']))
idx
# Index([2011-01-01 00:00:00, 86400000000000], dtype='object')

type(idx[0]), type(idx[-1])
# (pandas.tslib.Timestamp, int)
```
#### Expected Output
- result must be object dtype containing `Timestamp` and `Timedelta` (not `datetime` and `timedelta`)
#### output of `pd.show_versions()`

0.18.1
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "BUG/API: Index/Series concat inconsistencies"
    ],

}

{
    "id": 123539855,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/29954",
    "body": "Hi,\n\nI am trying to setup multiple environments (base, dev, prod) all getting their files from a git repository. I would like to be able to specify a root directory (or a branch) for each environment similar to ext_pillar. but in gitfs_remotes there seems to be no such option. for example:\n\n```\ngitfs_remotes:\n  - gitrepo:\n    - root: base (# base directory in the repo contains base sls files)\n    - env: base (# this option currently does not exists!)\n  - gitrepo: ( #same repo above or can be another repo)\n    - root: dev (# dev directory in the repo containing dev sls files)\n    - env: dev (# branch or directory)\n```\n\nyou get the idea.\n\nThere is only an option gitfs_base that allow me to specify which branch maps to the base environment. I would like to similarly map dev and prod to branches or directories.\n\nOne benefit of such structure is using the same state files to do different things in different environment such as managing different files:\n\nmanage_yum.sls\n\n```\n/etc/yum.conf\n  - file.managed:\n    - source: salt://files/yum.conf\n```\n\nrepo structure:\n\n```\n  /\n  base/\n    manage_yum.sls\n    files/\n      yum.conf\n  dev/\n    manage_yum.sls\n    files/\n      yum.conf\n```\n\nwill copy different files based on the env its in.\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "Hi,

I am trying to setup multiple environments (base, dev, prod) all getting their files from a git repository. I would like to be able to specify a root directory (or a branch) for each environment similar to ext_pillar. but in gitfs_remotes there seems to be no such option. for example:

```
gitfs_remotes:
  - gitrepo:
    - root: base (# base directory in the repo contains base sls files)
    - env: base (# this option currently does not exists!)
  - gitrepo: ( #same repo above or can be another repo)
    - root: dev (# dev directory in the repo containing dev sls files)
    - env: dev (# branch or directory)
```

you get the idea.

There is only an option gitfs_base that allow me to specify which branch maps to the base environment. I would like to similarly map dev and prod to branches or directories.

One benefit of such structure is using the same state files to do different things in different environment such as managing different files:

manage_yum.sls

```
/etc/yum.conf
  - file.managed:
    - source: salt://files/yum.conf
```

repo structure:

```
  /
  base/
    manage_yum.sls
    files/
      yum.conf
  dev/
    manage_yum.sls
    files/
      yum.conf
```

will copy different files based on the env its in.
"
    ],

        "Per-saltenv gitfs configuration parameters"
    ],

    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/3478",
    "body": "The `DataFrame` constructor supports numpy's ndarray of primitive type, recarray (or structured array) or a masked array of simple type. It breaks when given a masked recarray:\n\n``` python\n>>> a = np.ma.mrecords.fromrecords([(1,2)], names=['a', 'b'], mask=False)\n>>> pandas.DataFrame(a)\n...\nTypeError: cannot perform reduce with flexible type\n```\n\nTested at latest public release and HEAD.\n",

{
    "id": 169733735,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/35251",
    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\n\nDespite the documentation (`sys.doc state.single`), `state.single` cannot handle JSON-formatted keyword values right now. This isn't urgent, or critical right now, because one can still work around it using keyword arguments; but I just want to have it on record here.\n### Setup\n\nNothing special.\n### Steps to Reproduce Issue\n\nIf you try to pass everything (including the name of the state) in JSON, this is what happens\n\n```\n# salt-call --local state.single user.present '{\"fullname\":\"Salt user\",\"name\":\"salt\"}'\n[ERROR   ] An un-handled exception was caught by salt's global exception handler:\nKeyError: '__sls__'\nTraceback (most recent call last):\n  File \"/usr/bin/salt-call\", line 11, in <module>\n    salt_call()\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/scripts.py\", line 345, in salt_call\n    client.run()\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/cli/call.py\", line 58, in run\n    caller.run()\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/cli/caller.py\", line 134, in run\n    ret = self.call()\n type(data['name']).__name__)\nKeyError: '__sls__'\nTraceback (most recent call last):\n  File \"/usr/bin/salt-call\", line 11, in <module>\n    salt_call()\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/scripts.py\", line 345, in salt_call\n    client.run()\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/cli/call.py\", line 58, in run\n    caller.run()\n  File func(*args, **kwargs)\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/modules/state.py\", line 1345, in single\n    err = st_.verify_data(kwargs)\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/state.py\", line 986, in verify_data\n    data['name'], data['__sls__'], type(data['name']).__name__)\nKeyError: '__sls__'\n```\n\nIf you try to pass the name of the state as the required 2nd parameter instead of as a keyword argument (see signature of `salt.single` in the code), no errors get thrown, but you can see that nothing gets run (and no, it is not because the user's already present; it isn't as you can see). I've debugged the code in `user.present`, and it appears that the JSON parameters aren't being passed in (`user.present` sees `fullname` as `None`).\n\nHaving said that, I don't see why `user.present` should not go ahead and carry on (`fullname` = `None` is alright, even if it is the wrong value!), but that's another issue, and this is about `state.single` not being able to handle JSON\n\n```\n# id salt\nid: salt: no such user\n# salt-call --local state.single user.present salt '{\"fullname\":\"Salt user\"}'\nlocal:\n----------\n          ID: salt\n    Function: user.present\n      Result: None\n     Comment: User salt set to be added\n     Started: 06:18:09.143563\n    Duration: 5.362 ms\n     Changes:\n\nSummary for local\n------------\nSucceeded: 1 (unchanged=1)\nFailed:    0\n------------\nTotal states run:     1\n```\n\nIf you try to pass the name as a keyword argument, with the rest of the values as JSON (I am not saying that this should be supported or be a valid use case, btw; I am just trying it out to see what happens), you get the following. The error message is interesting (\"multiple values for keyword argument 'name'\"?):\n\n```\n# salt-call --local state.single user.present name=salt '{\"fullname\":\"salt user\"}'\n\nPassed invalid arguments: single() got multiple values for keyword argument 'name'.\n\nUsage:\n\n    Execute a single state function with the named kwargs, returns False if\n    insufficient data is sent to the command\n\n    By default, the values of the kwargs will be parsed as YAML. So, you can\n    specify lists values, or lists of single entry key-value maps, as you\n    would in a YAML salt file. Alternatively, JSON format of keyword values\n    is also supported.\n\n    CLI Example:\n\n    .. code-block:: bash\n\n        salt '*' state.single pkg.installed name=vim\n\n\n#\n```\n### Versions Report\n\n2016.3.2 on both minion and master\n",

{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question

Despite the documentation (`sys.doc state.single`), `state.single` cannot handle JSON-formatted keyword values right now. This isn't urgent, or critical right now, because one can still work around it using keyword arguments; but I just want to have it on record here.
### Setup

Nothing special.
### Steps to Reproduce Issue

If you try to pass everything (including the name of the state) in JSON, this is what happens

```
# salt-call --local state.single user.present '{"fullname":"Salt user","name":"salt"}'
[ERROR   ] An un-handled exception was caught by salt's global exception handler:
KeyError: '__sls__'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/salt-call", line 11, in <module>
    salt_call()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/scripts.py", line 345, in salt_call
    client.run()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/cli/call.py", line 58, in run
    caller.run()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/cli/caller.py", line 134, in run
    ret = self.call()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/cli/caller.py", line 197, in call
    ret['return'] = func(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/modules/state.py", line 1345, in single
    err = st_.verify_data(kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/state.py", line 986, in verify_data
    data['name'], data['__sls__'], type(data['name']).__name__)
KeyError: '__sls__'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/salt-call", line 11, in <module>
    salt_call()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/scripts.py", line 345, in salt_call
    client.run()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/cli/call.py", line 58, in run
    caller.run()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/cli/caller.py", line 134, in run
    ret = self.call()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/cli/caller.py", line 197, in call
    ret['return'] = func(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/modules/state.py", line 1345, in single
    err = st_.verify_data(kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/state.py", line 986, in verify_data
    data['name'], data['__sls__'], type(data['name']).__name__)
KeyError: '__sls__'
```

If you try to pass the name of the state as the required 2nd parameter instead of as a keyword argument (see signature of `salt.single` in the code), no errors get thrown, but you can see that nothing gets run (and no, it is not because the user's already present; it isn't as you can see). I've debugged the code in `user.present`, and it appears that the JSON parameters aren't being passed in (`user.present` sees `fullname` as `None`).

Having said that, I don't see why `user.present` should not go ahead and carry on (`fullname` = `None` is alright, even if it is the wrong value!), but that's another issue, and this is about `state.single` not being able to handle JSON

```
# id salt
id: salt: no such user
# salt-call --local state.single user.present salt '{"fullname":"Salt user"}'
local:
----------
          ID: salt
    Function: user.present
      Result: None
     Comment: User salt set to be added
     Started: 06:18:09.143563
    Duration: 5.362 ms
     Changes:

Summary for local
------------
Succeeded: 1 (unchanged=1)
Failed:    0
------------
Total states run:     1
```

If you try to pass the name as a keyword argument, with the rest of the values as JSON (I am not saying that this should be supported or be a valid use case, btw; I am just trying it out to see what happens), you get the following. The error message is interesting ("multiple values for keyword argument 'name'"?):

```
# salt-call --local state.single user.present name=salt '{"fullname":"salt user"}'

Passed invalid arguments: single() got multiple values for keyword argument 'name'.

Usage:

    Execute a single state function with the named kwargs, returns False if
    insufficient data is sent to the command

    By default, the values of the kwargs will be parsed as YAML. So, you can
    specify lists values, or lists of single entry key-value maps, as you
    would in a YAML salt file. Alternatively, JSON format of keyword values
    is also supported.

    CLI Example:

    .. code-block:: bash

        salt '*' state.single pkg.installed name=vim


#
```
### Versions Report

2016.3.2 on both minion and master
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "state.single cannot handle JSON format"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Bug",
            "description": "broken, incorrect, or confusing behavior"
        },
        {
            "name": "Core",
            "description": "relates to code central or existential to Salt"

            "name": "P4",
            "description": "Priority 4"
        },
        {
            "name": "severity-medium",
            "description": "3rd level, incorrect or bad functionality, confusing and lacks a work around"
        },
        {
            "name": "stale",
            "description": null
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

{
    "id": 478936404,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/14241",
    "body": "<!-- Please be sure you are following the instructions in the dev guidelines\r\nhttp://www.numpy.org/devdocs/dev/development_workflow.html\r\n-->\r\n\r\n<!-- We'd appreciate it if your commit message is properly formatted\r\nhttp://www.numpy.org/devdocs/dev/development_workflow.html#writing-the-commit-message\r\n-->\r\n\r\nReference  [ #14238](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/14238)\r\n\r\nI made the assumption that anyone who passes a string  `x` to the function `np.random.permutation(x)` most likely intend to shuffle the string in question. I suggest that if this isn't the desired behaviour, then I can flag an error instead of the segfault. ",

{
    "id": 321374469,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/11067",
    "body": "Related to #11024 \r\n\r\nBefore I start mucking around in the source code, I thought I'd try to draft a few unit tests for the behavior we'd expect for a \"simple\" mixture of datetime and float input to `histogramdd`.\r\n\r\nNaturally, datetime work can be a bit tricky; perhaps the most obvious issue that came up as I was drafting the unit test -- for datetime bin edges, is there an unambiguously clear \"winner\" in terms of a robust way to take i.e., \"days\" (or whatever datetime object the user provides) and \"cast\" it to a unit (like microseconds since the epoch) that can easily be subdivided for the various bin edge division scenarios?",

    "id": 231601885,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/41451",
    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\r\n\r\nWhile provisioning RHEL Vm's i used to get the following error,\r\nProvisioning failed. Disk size reduction is not supported. Current size is 34359738880 bytes, requested size is 32212255232 bytes.. ResizeDiskError \r\n\r\nAfter some investigation found out that by default the disk size being is 30GB in \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/cloud/clouds/azurearm.py\" at line #1021\r\n\r\nWhen i changed it to 40 it worked. Should the default be 40gb?",

{
    "id": 45917387,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/16660",
    "body": "The git_pillar \"ext_pillar\" is very specially handled by salt. See the following links for code:\n- https://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/develop/salt/master.py#L146\n- https://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/develop/salt/daemons/masterapi.py#L50\n\nThis makes the git_pillar work like no other ext pillar. The problems include at least the following:\n- Git_pillar cannot be stacked like more ext_pillars due to be run in a different place from other ext pillars.\n- Git_pillar does not follow the docs at http://docs.saltstack.com/en/latest/topics/development/external_pillars.html#ext-pillar. At the very least, the args for the ext_pillar function in salt.pillar.git_pillar are not like the documented args.\n",

{
    "id": 56544941,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/20379",
    "body": "In versions 2014.7.0 and 2014.7.1 on Windows 7, I see the following error:\n\n```\nC:\\Users\\blaffoy>salt-call pkg.list_pkgs\n[INFO    ] Executing command 'Powershell \" $msi = New-Object -ComObject WindowsInstaller.Installer; $msi.GetType().InvokeMember(\\'ProductsEx\\', \\'GetProperty\\', $null, $msi, (\\'\\', \\'s-1-1-0\\', 7)) | select @{       name=\\'name\\';       expression={$_.GetType().InvokeMember(\\'InstallProperty\\', \\'GetProperty\\', $null, $_, (\\'ProductName\\'))}     },     @{       name=\\'version\\';       expression={$_.GetType().InvokeMember(\\'InstallProperty\\', \\'GetProperty\\', $null, $_, (\\'VersionString\\'))}     } | Write-host \"' in directory 'C:\\\\Users\\\\blaffoy-admin'\n[ERROR   ] An un-handled exception was caught by salt's global exception handler:\nUnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0x82 in position 12: ordinal not in range(128)\nTraceback (most recent call last):\n  File \"<string>\", line 6, in <module>\n  File \"__main__.py\", line 726, in <module>\n  File \"__main__.py\", line 332, in bootstrap\n  File \"__main__.py\", line 359, in chainload\n  File \"__main__.py\", line 715, in _chainload\n  File \"__main__.py\", line 128, in <module>\n  File \"__main__salt-call__.py\", line 14, in <module>\n  File \"salt/scripts.py\", line 123, in salt_call\n  File \"salt/cli/__init__.py\", line 420, in run\n  File \"salt/cli/caller.py\", line 235, in run\n  File \"salt/output/__init__.py\", line 44, in display_output\n  File \"salt/output/nested.py\", line 122, in output\n  File \"salt/output/nested.py\", line 113, in display\n  File \"salt/output/nested.py\", line 105, in display\nUnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0x82 in position 12: ordinal not in range(128)\nTraceback (most recent call last):\n  File \"<string>\", line 6, in <module>\n  File \"__main__.py\", line 726, in <module>\n  File \"__main__.py\", line 332, in bootstrap\n  File \"__main__.py\", line 359, in chainload\n  File \"__main__.py\", line 715, in _chainload\n  File \"__main__.py\", line 128, in <module>\n  File \"__main__salt-call__.py\", line 14, in <module>\n  File \"salt/scripts.py\", line 123, in salt_call\n  File \"salt/cli/__init__.py\", line 420, in run\n  File \"salt/cli/caller.py\", line 235, in run\n  File \"salt/output/__init__.py\", line 44, in display_output\n  File \"salt/output/nested.py\", line 122, in output\n  File \"salt/output/nested.py\", line 113, in display\n  File \"salt/output/nested.py\", line 105, in display\nUnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0x82 in position 12: ordinal not in range(128)\n\nC:\\Users\\blaffoy>\n```\n\nIf I reconstruct the Powershell call shown in the output, the result looks correct:\n\n```\nPS C:\\> $msi.GetType().InvokeMember('ProductsEx', 'GetProperty', $null, $msi, ('', 's-1-1-0', 7)) | select @{       name='name';       expression={$_.GetType().InvokeMember('InstallProperty', 'GetProperty', $null, $_, ('ProductName'))}\n},     @{       name='version';       expression={$_.GetType().InvokeMember('InstallProperty', 'GetProperty', $null, $_, ('VersionString'))}     } | Write-host\n@{name=Microsoft Office OneNote MUI (English) 2010; version=14.0.7015.1000}\n@{name=Microsoft Office Standard 2010; version=14.0.7015.1000}\n@{name=Microsoft Office Shared Setup Metadata MUI (English) 2010; version=14.0.7015.1000}\n@{name=Microsoft Office Excel MUI (English) 2010; version=14.0.7015.1000}\n@{name=Microsoft Office Shared 64-bit Setup Metadata MUI (English) 2010; version=14.0.7015.1000}\n@{name=Microsoft Office 2010 Primary Interop Assemblies; version=14.0.4763.1150}\n@{name=Microsoft Office PowerPoint MUI (English) 2010; version=14.0.7015.1000}\n@{name=Microsoft Office Publisher MUI (English) 2010; version=14.0.7015.1000}\n@{name=Microsoft Office Outlook MUI (English) 2010; version=14.0.7015.1000}\n...\n```\n\nAlso, if I run this command from the master (running on Ubuntu, v2014.7.1), it looks okay:\n\n```\nblaffoy@salt:~/repos/pillar$ sudo salt my-minion pkg.list_pkgs\nsalt.myorg.local:\n    ----------\n     Tools for .Net 3.5:\n        3.11.50727\n    7-Zip 9.22 (x64 edition):\n        9.22.00.0\n    ????? Visual Studio 2012 Verification SDK - rus:\n        12.0.30501\n    AWS Tools for Windows:\n        3.7.413.0\n    Adobe Flash Player 15 ActiveX:\n        15.0.0.167\n    Adobe Flash Player 15 Plugin:\n        15.0.0.239\n    Adobe Reader XI (11.0.10):\n        11.0.10\n    Adobe Refresh Manager:\n        1.8.0\n    Application Insights Tools for Visual Studio 2013:\n        2.4\n    AzureTools.Notifications:\n...\n```\n\nI thought that I previously observed this error leading to all calls to pkg.install(ed) and pkg.remove(d) returning an error even if the package installed/uninstalled correctly as they would call pkg.list_pkgs on completion. I can't reproduce that behaviour now, so I may have been mistaken.\n",

{
    "body": [
        "In versions 2014.7.0 and 2014.7.1 on Windows 7, I see the following error:

```
C:\Users\blaffoy>salt-call pkg.list_pkgs
[INFO    ] Executing command 'Powershell " $msi = New-Object -ComObject WindowsInstaller.Installer; $msi.GetType().InvokeMember(\'ProductsEx\', \'GetProperty\', $null, $msi, (\'\', \'s-1-1-0\', 7)) | select @{       name=\'name\';       expression={$_.GetType().InvokeMember(\'InstallProperty\', \'GetProperty\', $null, $_, (\'ProductName\'))}     },     @{       name=\'version\';       expression={$_.GetType().InvokeMember(\'InstallProperty\', \'GetProperty\', $null, $_, (\'VersionString\'))}     } | Write-host "' in directory 'C:\\Users\\blaffoy-admin'
[ERROR   ] An un-handled exception was caught by salt's global exception handler:

C:\Users\blaffoy>

If I reconstruct the Powershell call shown in the output, the result looks correct:

```
PS C:\> $msi.GetType().InvokeMember('ProductsEx', 'GetProperty', $null, $msi, ('', 's-1-1-0', 7)) | select @{       name='name';       expression={$_.GetType().InvokeMember('InstallProperty', 'GetProperty', $null, $_, ('ProductName'))}

@{name=Microsoft Office Outlook MUI (English) 2010; version=14.0.7015.1000}

```

Also, if I run this command from the master (running on Ubuntu, v2014.7.1), it looks okay:

```
blaffoy@salt:~/repos/pillar$ sudo salt my-minion pkg.list_pkgs
salt.myorg.local:
    ----------

...
```

I thought that I previously observed this error leading to all calls to pkg.install(ed) and pkg.remove(d) returning an error even if the package installed/uninstalled correctly as they would call pkg.list_pkgs on completion. I can't reproduce that behaviour now, so I may have been mistaken.

{
    "id": 185231064,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/14494",
    "body": "- [ ] closes #xxxx\n- [x] tests added / passed\n- [x] passes `git diff upstream/master | flake8 --diff`\n- [ ] whatsnew entry\n\nI was thinking about code paths that give away borrowed references to strings and realized that interned strings can be accessed even when their refcount is 1. This is because the intern table holds a \"weak ref\" to the string. This allows the string to be garbage collected normally; however, if a user creates an interned string with exactly one reference and feeds it to move, you could later get a second reference to the **same** string object by calling intern with a copy of the old string. The data backing the old string may have been mutated so you will get very strange results. I am almost certain that no on has run into this since `move_into_mutable_buffer` was added but it doesn't hurt to add this quick check to prevent broken usage like this in the future.\n\nThis only affects python 2 because bytes objects cannot be interned in python 3.\n",
    "user": {
        "id": 3064397,
        "url": "https://api.github.com/users/llllllllll",

{
    "id": 179003649,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/36549",
    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\n\nThe mount.mounted state documentation (https://docs.saltstack.com/en/latest/ref/states/all/salt.states.mount.html) claims that the 'user' argument is \"The user to own the mount; this defaults to the user salt is running as on the minion.\" This implies that the user given in that argument will own the mount. But in fact, the user argument controls which user executes the mount command. Though this can have the net result of that user owning the mount in some cases, it leads to the problem of passed options causing errors because only root can specify mount options (at least on CentOS7). This results in failed state execution.\n\nThe documentation should be updated to state the 'user' argument is the user the mount command runs as, and that could restrict which arguments can also be specified along with the user argument.\n\nI had hoped the mount command would be run as root so all the arguments worked, then the state ensured the mountpoint was chown'd to the 'user'. Bummer.\n### Setup\n#### Contents of nfs-test.sls:\n\n```\napp1-nfs-mnt:\n  mount.mounted:\n    - name: \"/srv/appdata/app1\"\n    - device: \"10.10.182.251:/srv/exports/app1\"\n    - fstype: \"nfs\"\n    - opts: \"vers=3\"\n    - persist: True\n    - mkmnt: True\n    - user: \"tomcat\"\n```\n### Steps to Reproduce Issue\n\n```\nsalt-call state.apply nfs-test saltenv=dev -l debug\n\n[INFO extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question

The mount.mounted state documentation (https://docs.saltstack.com/en/latest/ref/states/all/salt.states.mount.html) claims that the 'user' argument is "The user to own the mount; this defaults to the user salt is running as on the minion." This implies that the user given in that argument will own the mount. But in fact, the user argument controls which user executes the mount command. Though this can have the net result of that user owning the mount in some cases, it leads to the problem of passed options causing errors because only root can specify mount options (at least on CentOS7). This results in failed state execution.

The documentation should be updated to state the 'user' argument is the user the mount command runs as, and that could restrict which arguments can also be specified along with the user argument.

I had hoped the mount command would be run as root so all the arguments worked, then the state ensured the mountpoint was chown'd to the 'user'. Bummer.
### Setup
#### Contents of nfs-test.sls:

```
app1-nfs-mnt:
  mount.mounted:
    - name: "/srv/appdata/app1"
    - device: "10.10.182.251:/srv/exports/app1"
    - fstype: "nfs"
    - opts: "vers=3"
    - persist: True
    - mkmnt: True
    - user: "tomcat"
```
### Steps to Reproduce Issue

```
salt-call state.apply nfs-test saltenv=dev -l debug

[INFO    ] Executing command 'mount -o vers=3 -t nfs 10.10.182.251:/srv/exports/app1 /srv/appdata/app1 ' as user 'tomcat' in directory '/opt/tomcat'
[ERROR   ] Command 'mount -o vers=3 -t nfs 10.10.182.251:/srv/exports/app1 /srv/appdata/app1 ' failed with return code: 1
[ERROR   ] stderr: mount: only root can use "--options" option
[ERROR   ] retcode: 1
```
### Versions Report

MASTER:

```
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2016.3.1

Dependency Versions:
           cffi: 0.8.6
       cherrypy: 3.2.2
       dateutil: Not Installed
          gitdb: 0.6.4
      gitpython: Not Installed
          ioflo: Not Installed
         Jinja2: 2.7.2
        libgit2: 0.21.0
        libnacl: Not Installed
       M2Crypto: 0.21.1
           Mako: Not Installed
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.4.7
   mysql-python: Not Installed
      pycparser: 2.14
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
         pygit2: 0.21.4
         Python: 2.7.5 (default, Nov 20 2015, 02:00:19)
   python-gnupg: Not Installed
         PyYAML: 3.11
          PyZMQ: 14.7.0
           RAET: Not Installed
          smmap: 0.9.0
        timelib: Not Installed
        Tornado: 4.2.1
            ZMQ: 4.0.5

System Versions:
           dist: centos 7.2.1511 Core
        machine: x86_64
        release: 3.10.0-327.22.2.el7.x86_64
         system: Linux
        version: CentOS Linux 7.2.1511 Core
```

MINION:

```
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2016.3.2

Dependency Versions:
           cffi: Not Installed
       cherrypy: Not Installed
       dateutil: Not Installed
          gitdb: Not Installed
      gitpython: Not Installed
          ioflo: Not Installed
         Jinja2: 2.7.2
        libgit2: Not Installed
        libnacl: Not Installed
       M2Crypto: 0.21.1
           Mako: Not Installed
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.4.7
   mysql-python: Not Installed
      pycparser: Not Installed
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
         pygit2: Not Installed
         Python: 2.7.5 (default, Nov 20 2015, 02:00:19)
   python-gnupg: Not Installed
         PyYAML: 3.11
          PyZMQ: 15.3.0
           RAET: Not Installed
          smmap: Not Installed
        timelib: Not Installed
        Tornado: 4.2.1
            ZMQ: 4.1.4

System Versions:
           dist: centos 7.2.1511 Core
        machine: x86_64
        release: 3.10.0-327.22.2.el7.x86_64
         system: Linux
        version: CentOS Linux 7.2.1511 Core
```

{
    "id": 40421161,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/15049",
    "body": "I'm deploying collectd to a bunch of Ubuntu hosts but unfortunately it's packaged a little silly:\n%> apt-cache depends collectd\ncollectd\n  Depends: collectd-core\n  Depends: libc6\n  Depends: librrd4\n  Recommends: iptables\n  Recommends: libcurl3-gnutls\n  Recommends: libdbi1\n  Recommends: libesmtp6\n  Recommends: libgcrypt11\n  Recommends: libglib2.0-0\n  Recommends: libmemcached10\n  Recommends: libmodbus5\n  Recommends: libmysqlclient18\n  Recommends: libnotify4\n  Recommends: libopenipmi0\n  Recommends: liboping0\n  Recommends: libpcap0.8\n  Recommends: libperl5.14\n  Recommends: libpq5\n  Recommends: libpython2.7\n  Recommends: librabbitmq1\n  Recommends: librrd4\n  Recommends: libsensors4\n  Recommends: libsnmp30\n  Recommends: libtokyotyrant3\n  Recommends: libupsclient1\n  Recommends: libvarnishapi1\n  Recommends: libvirt0\n  Recommends: libxml2\n  Recommends: libyajl2\n\nEspecially the libnotify4 recommendation is terrible since it pulls in wayland, libxinerama, icon themes and all kinds of sillyness for a headless machine where I just want to have collectd. As of now I can't find any way to control handling of Recommends -dependencies on a per package level. If I was installing on the cli I'd just: aptitude install --without-recommends collectd\n\nAny ideas how to handle this gracefully? Disabling recommends system wide feels like a bad idea.\n",

        "id": 1683369,
        "url": "https://api.github.com/users/Artanicus",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "I'm deploying collectd to a bunch of Ubuntu hosts but unfortunately it's packaged a little silly:
%> apt-cache depends collectd
collectd
  Depends: collectd-core
  Depends: libc6
  Depends: librrd4
  Recommends: iptables
  Recommends: libcurl3-gnutls
  Recommends: libdbi1
  Recommends: libesmtp6
  Recommends: libgcrypt11
  Recommends: libglib2.0-0
  Recommends: libmemcached10
  Recommends: libmodbus5
  Recommends: libmysqlclient18
  Recommends: libnotify4
  Recommends: libopenipmi0
  Recommends: liboping0
  Recommends: libpcap0.8
  Recommends: libperl5.14
  Recommends: libpq5
  Recommends: libpython2.7
  Recommends: librabbitmq1
  Recommends: librrd4
  Recommends: libsensors4
  Recommends: libsnmp30
  Recommends: libtokyotyrant3
  Recommends: libupsclient1
  Recommends: libvarnishapi1
  Recommends: libvirt0
  Recommends: libxml2
  Recommends: libyajl2

Especially the libnotify4 recommendation is terrible since it pulls in wayland, libxinerama, icon themes and all kinds of sillyness for a headless machine where I just want to have collectd. As of now I can't find any way to control handling of Recommends -dependencies on a per package level. If I was installing on the cli I'd just: aptitude install --without-recommends collectd

Any ideas how to handle this gracefully? Disabling recommends system wide feels like a bad idea.
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "pkg.installed options to control "Recommends" dependencies"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Feature",
            "description": "new functionality including changes to functionality and code refactors, etc."
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

{
    "id": 27594806,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/10445",
    "body": "I had a look at the code to see if I could fix this myself, but I can't find the ubuntu specific service module that is supposed to do this, so if someone could give me a pointer I will have a go at fixing it.\n\n```\nvagrant@buildmgt:~$ uname -a\nLinux buildmgt01 3.2.0-23-generic-pae #36-Ubuntu SMP Tue Apr 10 22:19:09 UTC 2012 i686 i686 i386 GNU/Linux\nvagrant@buildmgt:~$ sudo service postgresql stop\n * Stopping PostgreSQL 9.1 database server                                           [ OK ] \nvagrant@buildmgt:~$ sudo salt-call --local service.status postgresql\n[INFO    ] Executing command 'service postgresql status' in directory '/home/vagrant'\nlocal:\n    True\nvagrant@buildmgt:~$ sudo service postgresql status\nRunning clusters: \nvagrant@buildmgt:~$ pgrep -lf postgres\nvagrant@buildmgt:~$ \n```\n",

{
    "id": 31137664,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/11870",
    "body": "It would be really nice if grains.present (and absent of course) could get support for nested grains.\n\nExample:\n\n```\nicinga:\n  Apache SSL:\n    command: check_https\n    params: -H localhost -p 443 -S\n```\n\nThanks to @whiteinge I know that the following workaround is possible but a more native function would be a lot nicer. Just attaching it to give a better understanding of the suggested feature.\n\n```\n{% if not 'icinga' in grains %}\nset_icinga_grain:\n  module:\n    - run\n    - name: grains.setval\n    - key: icinga\n    - val:\n        Apache SSL:\n          command: check_https\n          params: -H localhost -p 443 -S\n{% endif %} \n```\n",
    "user": {
        "id": 296982,
        "url": "https://api.github.com/users/gpkvt",
        "type": "User",
        "login": "gpkvt",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "It would be really nice if grains.present (and absent of course) could get support for nested grains.

Example:

```
icinga:
  Apache SSL:
    command: check_https
    params: -H localhost -p 443 -S
```

Thanks to @whiteinge I know that the following workaround is possible but a more native function would be a lot nicer. Just attaching it to give a better understanding of the suggested feature.

```
{% if not 'icinga' in grains %}
set_icinga_grain:
  module:
    - run
    - name: grains.setval
    - key: icinga
    - val:
        Apache SSL:
          command: check_https
          params: -H localhost -p 443 -S
{% endif %} 
```
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "Nested Grain-Support for grains.present / grains.absent"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Feature",
            "description": "new functionality including changes to functionality and code refactors, etc."
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

{
    "id": 45027508,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/16409",
    "body": "Currently it looks like Salt just uses urllib2.  Urllib2 doesn't work well with SNI servers.\n\nIn practice, this bit us as the Docker folks started hosting their apt repository GPG key on a SNI server.\n\nYou can see this with raw python:\n\n```\npython2.7 -c \"import urllib2; req = urllib2.Request('https://get.docker.com/gpg'); response = urllib2.urlopen(req); print response.read()\"\n```\n\nWe have worked around this with the Docker guys (https://get.docker.io doesn't use SNI) but there is a good chance it'll break again in the future.\n\nI'm not sure how to fix this as SSL support in python has a long and painful history, but it might be worth switching to alternate download frameworks.  Or fall back on calling curl/wget in some cases?\n\n/cc @bgrant0607\n",
    "user": {

    392     if not issubclass_(arg1, generic):
--> 393         arg1 = dtype(arg1).type
    394     if not issubclass_(arg2, generic):
    395         arg2_orig = arg2

TypeError: data type not understood

In [4]: pd.DataFrame(columns=['a'], dtype='float')
Out[4]:
Empty DataFrame
Columns: [a]
Index: []
```

#### Problem description

When trying to create an empty dataframe, one can specify some dtypes, like `'float'`, but `dtype='string'` raises `TypeError: data type not understood`.

#### Expected Output

    "body": "_Original ticket http://projects.scipy.org/numpy/ticket/893 on 2008-08-26 by trac user cscott, assigned to @pierregm._\n\nIn line 3256 of numpy/ma/core.py, the following code appears:\n inner.**doc** += doc_note(\"Masked values are replaced by 0.\")\n\nThis line fails when python is invoked with the -OO option, which\nremoves doc strings to save memory, since inner.**doc** will be None\nand a TypeError will be raised trying to add a string to None.  Adding\na guard like: 'if inner.**doc**:' would fix this bug.\n",

    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\r\n\r\nI just tried to upgrade the salt-master package, but the restart of the service during that upgrade fails. That leaves the salt-master package as unconfigured for dpkg and unusable on the system.\r\n\r\nError messages ( from /var/log/salt/master) during the restart are:\r\n\r\n2018-10-25 06:28:32,267 [salt.log.setup   :1165][ERROR   ][6901] An un-handled exception was caught by salt's global exception handler:\r\nImportError: No module named concurrent\r\nTraceback (most recent call last):\r\n  File \"/usr/bin/salt-master\", line 22, in <module>\r\n    salt_master()\r\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/scripts.py\", line 97, in salt_master\r\n    master.start()\r\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/cli/daemons.py\", line 211, in start\r\n    super(Master, self).start()\r\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/utils/parsers.py\", line 1044, in start\r\n    self.prepare()\r\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/cli/daemons.py\", line 191, in prepare\r\n    import salt.master\r\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/master.py\", line 35, in <module>\r\n    import salt.client.ssh.client\r\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/client/ssh/__init__.py\", line 47, in <module>\r\n    import salt.utils.thin\r\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/utils/thin.py\", line 16, in <module>\r\n    import concurrent\r\nImportError: No module named concurrent\r\n\r\n### Setup\r\n\r\nThis ist just a regular, up-to-date, Debian Stretch. Upgrade for the Salt Packages were available for:\r\nsalt-cloud, salt-minion, salt-master, salt-common and salt-api\r\nwhere version \"2018.3.2+ds-1\" would've been upgraded to \"2018.3.3+ds-1\".\r\n\r\n### Steps to Reproduce Issue\r\n\r\n1. Install salt-master version 2018.3.2+ds-1 from repo https://repo.saltstack.com/apt/debian/9/amd64/latest stretch main\r\n2. Upgrade theat Package to 2018.3.3+ds-1 from the same repository with the help of apt\r\n\r\n### Versions Report\r\n\r\nSalt Version:\r\n           Salt: 2018.3.3\r\n\r\nDependency Versions:\r\n           cffi: 0.8.6\r\n       cherrypy: 3.5.0\r\n       dateutil: 2.5.3\r\n      docker-py: Not Installed\r\n          gitdb: 2.0.0\r\n      gitpython: 2.1.1\r\n          ioflo: Not Installed\r\n         Jinja2: 2.9.4\r\n        libgit2: Not Installed\r\n        libnacl: Not Installed\r\n       M2Crypto: Not Installed\r\n           Mako: Not Installed\r\n   msgpack-pure: Not Installed\r\n msgpack-python: 0.4.8\r\n   mysql-python: Not Installed\r\n      pycparser: 2.10\r\n       pycrypto: 2.6.1\r\n   pycryptodome: Not Installed\r\n         pygit2: Not Installed\r\n         Python: 2.7.13 (default, Sep 26 2018, 18:42:22)\r\n   python-gnupg: Not Installed\r\n         PyYAML: 3.12\r\n          PyZMQ: 16.0.2\r\n           RAET: Not Installed\r\n          smmap: 2.0.1\r\n        timelib: Not Installed\r\n        Tornado: 4.4.3\r\n            ZMQ: 4.2.1\r\n\r\nSystem Versions:\r\n           dist: debian 9.5\r\n         locale: UTF-8\r\n        machine: x86_64\r\n        release: 4.9.0-8-amd64\r\n         system: Linux\r\n        version: debian 9.5\r\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question

I just tried to upgrade the salt-master package, but the restart of the service during that upgrade fails. That leaves the salt-master package as unconfigured for dpkg and unusable on the system.

Error messages ( from /var/log/salt/master) during the restart are:

2018-10-25 06:28:32,267 [salt.log.setup   :1165][ERROR   ][6901] An un-handled exception was caught by salt's global exception handler:
ImportError: No module named concurrent
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/salt-master", line 22, in <module>
    salt_master()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/scripts.py", line 97, in salt_master
    master.start()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/cli/daemons.py", line 211, in start
    super(Master, self).start()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/utils/parsers.py", line 1044, in start
    self.prepare()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/cli/daemons.py", line 191, in prepare
    import salt.master
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/master.py", line 35, in <module>
    import salt.client.ssh.client
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/client/ssh/__init__.py", line 47, in <module>
    import salt.utils.thin
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/utils/thin.py", line 16, in <module>
    import concurrent
ImportError: No module named concurrent

### Setup

This ist just a regular, up-to-date, Debian Stretch. Upgrade for the Salt Packages were available for:
salt-cloud, salt-minion, salt-master, salt-common and salt-api
where version "2018.3.2+ds-1" would've been upgraded to "2018.3.3+ds-1".

### Steps to Reproduce Issue

1. Install salt-master version 2018.3.2+ds-1 from repo https://repo.saltstack.com/apt/debian/9/amd64/latest stretch main
2. Upgrade theat Package to 2018.3.3+ds-1 from the same repository with the help of apt

### Versions Report

Salt Version:
           Salt: 2018.3.3

Dependency Versions:
           cffi: 0.8.6
       cherrypy: 3.5.0
       dateutil: 2.5.3
      docker-py: Not Installed
          gitdb: 2.0.0
      gitpython: 2.1.1
          ioflo: Not Installed
         Jinja2: 2.9.4
        libgit2: Not Installed
        libnacl: Not Installed
       M2Crypto: Not Installed
           Mako: Not Installed
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.4.8
   mysql-python: Not Installed
      pycparser: 2.10
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
   pycryptodome: Not Installed
         pygit2: Not Installed
         Python: 2.7.13 (default, Sep 26 2018, 18:42:22)
   python-gnupg: Not Installed
         PyYAML: 3.12
          PyZMQ: 16.0.2
           RAET: Not Installed
          smmap: 2.0.1
        timelib: Not Installed
        Tornado: 4.4.3
            ZMQ: 4.2.1

System Versions:
           dist: debian 9.5
         locale: UTF-8
        machine: x86_64
        release: 4.9.0-8-amd64
         system: Linux
        version: debian 9.5
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "salt-master debian package upgrade to 2018.3.3+ds-1 fails "
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Bug",
            "description": "broken, incorrect, or confusing behavior"
        },
        {
            "name": "severity-medium",
            "description": "3rd level, incorrect or bad functionality, confusing and lacks a work around"
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

{
    "body": [
        "#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example if possible

```python
In [2]: df = pd.DataFrame([[1, 2]], columns=pd.MultiIndex.from_tuples([('', 'first'), ('2', 'second')]))

In [3]: df
Out[3]: 
             2
  first second
0     1      2

In [4]: print(df.to_latex())
\begin{tabular}{lrr}
\toprule
{} &      2 \\
{} & first & second \\
\midrule
0 &     1 &      2 \\
\bottomrule
\end{tabular}
```

#### Problem description

Notice that the headers line has 2 elements rather than 3.

#### Expected Output

``` python
\begin{tabular}{lrr}
\toprule
{} &    {} &      2 \\
{} & first & second \\
\midrule
0 &     1 &      2 \\
\bottomrule
\end{tabular}
```

    "body": "With the following pillar files:\n- `top.sls`:\n  \n  ```\n  base:\n    '*':\n      - roles\n    'I@roles:foo':\n      - match: compound\n      - foo\n  ```\n- `roles.sls`:\n  \n  ```\n  roles:\n    - foo\n  ```\n- `foo.sls`:\n  \n  ```\n  foo: bar\n  ```\n\nI get the following error in the minions:\n\n```\n2015-08-28 02:27:29,664 [salt.pillar      ][ERROR   ][17476] Got a bad pillar from master, type str, expecting dict: \n```\n\nand the following error in `/var/log/salt/master`:\n\n```\n2015-08-28 02:27:57,036 [salt.master      ][ERROR   ][14016] Error in function _pillar:\nTraceback (most recent call last):\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/master.py\", line 1457, in run_func\n    ret = getattr(self, func)(load)\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/master.py\", line 1220, in _pillar\n    data = pillar.compile_pillar(pillar_dirs=pillar_dirs)\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/pillar/__init__.py\", line 578, in compile_pillar\n    matches = self.top_matches(top)\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/pillar/__init__.py\", line 353, in top_matches\n    self.opts.get('nodegroups', {}),\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/minion.py\", line 2656, in confirm_top\n    return getattr(self, funcname)(match)\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/minion.py\", line 2848, in compound_match\n    '@'.join(comps[1:])\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/minion.py\", line 2749, in pillar_match\n    self.opts['pillar'], tgt, delimiter=delimiter\nKeyError: 'pillar'\n```\n\nIf I set `ext_pillar_first: True` in `/etc/salt/master` then the errors go away, but the `foo:bar` pillar setting isn't set (though `roles:foo` is).\n\nI'm using Salt 2015.5.3 (from the saltstack/salt PPA) on Ubuntu 14.04 64-bit server.\n",
    "user": {

{
    "body": [
        "With the following pillar files:
- `top.sls`:
  
  ```
  base:
    '*':
      - roles
    'I@roles:foo':
      - match: compound
      - foo
  ```
- `roles.sls`:
  
  ```
  roles:
    - foo
  ```
- `foo.sls`:
  
  ```
  foo: bar
  ```

I get the following error in the minions:

```
2015-08-28 02:27:29,664 [salt.pillar      ][ERROR   ][17476] Got a bad pillar from master, type str, expecting dict: 
```

and the following error in `/var/log/salt/master`:

```
2015-08-28 02:27:57,036 [salt.master      ][ERROR   ][14016] Error in function _pillar:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/master.py", line 1457, in run_func
    ret = getattr(self, func)(load)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/master.py", line 1220, in _pillar
    data = pillar.compile_pillar(pillar_dirs=pillar_dirs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/pillar/__init__.py", line 578, in compile_pillar
    matches = self.top_matches(top)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/pillar/__init__.py", line 353, in top_matches
    self.opts.get('nodegroups', {}),
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/minion.py", line 2656, in confirm_top
    return getattr(self, funcname)(match)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/minion.py", line 2848, in compound_match
    '@'.join(comps[1:])
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/minion.py", line 2749, in pillar_match
    self.opts['pillar'], tgt, delimiter=delimiter
KeyError: 'pillar'
```

If I set `ext_pillar_first: True` in `/etc/salt/master` then the errors go away, but the `foo:bar` pillar setting isn't set (though `roles:foo` is).

I'm using Salt 2015.5.3 (from the saltstack/salt PPA) on Ubuntu 14.04 64-bit server.
"

{
    "id": 7726139,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/1265",
    "body": "_Original ticket http://projects.scipy.org/numpy/ticket/667 on 2008-02-24 by trac user otizonaizit, assigned to unknown._\n\nDear numpy devs, after changeset 3854 ( http://projects.scipy.org/scipy/numpy/changeset/3854 ) dotblas only gets built when ATLAS is installed (LAPACK+BLAS is not enough anymore). This prevents the python-numpy debian package ( http://packages.debian.org/sid/python-numpy ) from being built with dotblas support (see debian bug for details: http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=464784 ). What is the reason for such a dependency? Shouldn't the API for BLAS and ATLAS routines be exactly the same so that they can be used interchangeably? Simply adding a dependency on ATLAS for python-numpy in debian at the moment is not feasible (see the debian bug report for more details).\n\nThank you for your attention and keep up with the very good work!\n\ntiziano\n\nps: I've set the priority for this bug report to \"high\" and severity to \"critical\", because numpy on debian is presently _really_ slow, at the point that is almost unusable, forcing users to build it from source. \n",

{
    "id": 110616715,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/27820",
    "body": "Upgrading from salt 2015.5.3 (Lithium) to 2015.8.0 (Beryllium) fails on Ubuntu 14.04.3 LTS (GNU/Linux 3.13.0-44-generic x86_64) due to unmet python-tornado dependency. \n\nFirst, trying to install salt-master fails:\n\n```\napt-get install salt-master\nReading package lists... Done\nBuilding dependency tree\nReading state information... Done\nSome packages could not be installed. This may mean that you have\nrequested an impossible situation or if you are using the unstable\ndistribution that some required packages have not yet been created\nor been moved out of Incoming.\nThe following information may help to resolve the situation:\n\nThe following packages have unmet dependencies:\n salt-master : Depends: salt-common (= 2015.8.0+ds-1) but it is not going to be installed\nE: Unable to correct problems, you have held broken packages.\n```\n\nThen, trying to install salt-common fails:\n\n```\napt-get install salt-common=2015.8.0+ds-1\nReading package lists... Done\nBuilding dependency tree\nReading state information... Done\nSome packages could not be installed. This may mean that you have\nrequested an impossible situation or if you are using the unstable\ndistribution that some required packages have not yet been created\nor been moved out of Incoming.\nThe following information may help to resolve the situation:\n\nThe following packages have unmet dependencies:\n salt-common : Depends: python-tornado (>= 4.2.1) but it is not going to be installed\n               Recommends: python-mako but it is not going to be installed\nE: Unable to correct problems, you have held broken packages.\n```\n\nThe version of python-tornado required is not available on apt, and installing via pip does not seem to be a good idea. However, the deb package for tornado can be found on your repo (http://repo.saltstack.com/apt/ubuntu/ubuntu14/pool/main/p/python-tornado/) so as a temporary workaround was added to our repo and installed via apt. \n\nSince tornado is considered experimental for this release according to the release notes, it should not block installation.\n",
    "user": {
        "id": 4719415,
        "url": "https://api.github.com/users/ramonamis",
        "type": "User",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "Upgrading from salt 2015.5.3 (Lithium) to 2015.8.0 (Beryllium) fails on Ubuntu 14.04.3 LTS (GNU/Linux 3.13.0-44-generic x86_64) due to unmet python-tornado dependency. 

First, trying to install salt-master fails:

```
apt-get install salt-master
Reading package lists... Done
Building dependency tree
Reading state information... Done
Some packages could not be installed. This may mean that you have
requested an impossible situation or if you are using the unstable
distribution that some required packages have not yet been created
or been moved out of Incoming.
The following information may help to resolve the situation:

The following packages have unmet dependencies:
 salt-master : Depends: salt-common (= 2015.8.0+ds-1) but it is not going to be installed
E: Unable to correct problems, you have held broken packages.
```

Then, trying to install salt-common fails:

```
apt-get install salt-common=2015.8.0+ds-1
Reading package lists... Done
Building dependency tree
Reading state information... Done
Some packages could not be installed. This may mean that you have
requested an impossible situation or if you are using the unstable
distribution that some required packages have not yet been created
or been moved out of Incoming.
The following information may help to resolve the situation:

The following packages have unmet dependencies:
 salt-common : Depends: python-tornado (>= 4.2.1) but it is not going to be installed
               Recommends: python-mako but it is not going to be installed
E: Unable to correct problems, you have held broken packages.
```

The version of python-tornado required is not available on apt, and installing via pip does not seem to be a good idea. However, the deb package for tornado can be found on your repo (http://repo.saltstack.com/apt/ubuntu/ubuntu14/pool/main/p/python-tornado/) so as a temporary workaround was added to our repo and installed via apt. 

Since tornado is considered experimental for this release according to the release notes, it should not block installation.
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "salt-master does not install due to python tornado dependency"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Bug",
            "description": "broken, incorrect, or confusing behavior"
        },
        {
            "name": "P2",
            "description": "Priority 2"
        },
        {
            "name": "Packaging",
            "description": "Related to packaging of Salt, not Salt's support for package management."
        },
        {
            "name": "Platform",
            "description": "Relates to OS, containers, platform-based utilities like FS, system based apps"
        },
        {
            "name": "fixed-pls-verify",
            "description": "fix is linked, bug author to confirm fix"
        },
        {
            "name": "info-needed",
            "description": "waiting for more info"
        },
        {
            "name": "severity-high",
            "description": "2nd top severity, seen by most users, causes major problems"
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

{
    "id": 254377111,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/43285",
    "body": "salt.states.gem should support the --user-install option, which installs gems under ~/.gem\r\n\r\ne.g.\r\n```\r\nfpm:\r\n  gem.installed:\r\n    - user-install: bob\r\n```\r\n\r\nWould be the equivalent of Bob running:\r\n\r\n`gem install --user-install fpm`\r\n\r\nThis allows Salt to install gems for a particular user without interfering with the system Ruby installation or worrying about permissions.\r\n\r\nNote:  for this to work for Bob, he/she would need to have the following in their ~/.bashrc.  This is a separate responsibility, but should perhaps be noted in the documentation pages for salt.states.gem and salt.modules.gem.\r\n\r\n```\r\nif which ruby >/dev/null && which gem >/dev/null; then\r\n    PATH=\"$(ruby -rubygems -e 'puts Gem.user_dir')/bin:$PATH\"\r\nfi\r\n```",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "salt.states.gem should support the --user-install option, which installs gems under ~/.gem

e.g.
```
fpm:
  gem.installed:
    - user-install: bob
```

Would be the equivalent of Bob running:

`gem install --user-install fpm`

This allows Salt to install gems for a particular user without interfering with the system Ruby installation or worrying about permissions.

Note:  for this to work for Bob, he/she would need to have the following in their ~/.bashrc.  This is a separate responsibility, but should perhaps be noted in the documentation pages for salt.states.gem and salt.modules.gem.

```
if which ruby >/dev/null && which gem >/dev/null; then
    PATH="$(ruby -rubygems -e 'puts Gem.user_dir')/bin:$PATH"
fi
```"
    ],
    "title": [
        "Support local user install of Ruby Gems"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Duplicate",
            "description": "Duplicate of another issue or PR - will be closed"
        },
        {
            "name": "Feature",
            "description": "new functionality including changes to functionality and code refactors, etc."
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

    "body": "_Original ticket http://projects.scipy.org/numpy/ticket/1220 on 2009-09-11 by trac user sole, assigned to @cournape._\n\nHello,\n\n_dotblas.pyd is missing in the windows nosse architecture for python 2.6 It is present for python 2.5.\n\nOf course, that leads to performance issues under python 2.6.\n\nSee\n\n[Numpy-discussion] Dot product performance on python 2.6 (windows)\n\ndated Sep. 11, 2009.\n\nBest regards,\n\nArmando\n",

        "_Original ticket http://projects.scipy.org/numpy/ticket/1220 on 2009-09-11 by trac user sole, assigned to @cournape._

Hello,

_dotblas.pyd is missing in the windows nosse architecture for python 2.6 It is present for python 2.5.

Of course, that leads to performance issues under python 2.6.

See

[Numpy-discussion] Dot product performance on python 2.6 (windows)

dated Sep. 11, 2009.

Best regards,

Armando
"
    ],

        "_dotblas.pyd missing in NOSSE  numpy-1.3.0-win32-superpack-python2.6.exe (Trac #1220)"

body:
{
    "id": 1007216199,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/19955",
    "body": "* Resolve divide by zero in reciprocal #18555\r\n\r\nclang has an optimization bug where a vector that is only partially loaded / stored will get narrowed to only the lanes used, which can be fine in some cases. However, in numpy's `reciprocal` function a partial load is explicitly extended to the full width of the register (filled with '1's) to avoid divide-by-zero. clang's optimization ignores the explicit filling with '1's.\r\n\r\nThe changes here insert a dummy `volatile` variable. This convinces clang not to narrow the load and ignore the explicit filling of '1's.\r\n\r\n`volatile` can be expensive since it forces loads / stores to refresh contents whenever the variable is used. numpy has its own template / macro system that'll expand the loop function below for sqrt, absolute, square, and reciprocal. Additionally, the loop can be called on a full array if there's overlap between src and dst. Consequently, we try to limit the scope that we need to apply `volatile`. Intention is it should only be needed when compiling with clang, against Apple arm64, and only for the `reciprocal` function. Moreover, `volatile` is only needed when a vector is partially loaded.\r\n\r\nTesting:\r\nBeyond fixing the cases mentioned in the GitHub issue, the changes here also resolve several failures in numpy's test suite.\r\n\r\nBefore:\r\n```\r\nFAILED numpy/core/tests/test_scalarmath.py::TestBaseMath::test_blocked - RuntimeWarning: divide by zero encountered in reciprocal\r\nFAILED numpy/core/tests/test_ufunc.py::TestUfuncGenericLoops::test_unary_PyUFunc_O_O_method_full[reciprocal] - AssertionError: FloatingPointError not raised\r\nFAILED numpy/core/tests/test_umath.py::TestPower::test_power_float - RuntimeWarning: divide by zero encountered in reciprocal\r\nFAILED numpy/core/tests/test_umath.py::TestSpecialFloats::test_tan - AssertionError: FloatingPointError not raised by tan\r\nFAILED numpy/core/tests/test_umath.py::TestAVXUfuncs::test_avx_based_ufunc - RuntimeWarning: divide by zero encountered in reciprocal\r\nFAILED numpy/linalg/tests/test_linalg.py::TestNormDouble::test_axis - RuntimeWarning: divide by zero encountered in reciprocal\r\nFAILED numpy/linalg/tests/test_linalg.py::TestNormSingle::test_axis - RuntimeWarning: divide by zero encountered in reciprocal\r\nFAILED numpy/linalg/tests/test_linalg.py::TestNormInt64::test_axis - RuntimeWarning: divide by zero encountered in reciprocal\r\n8 failed, 14759 passed, 204 skipped, 1268 deselected, 34 xfailed in 69.90s (0:01:09)\r\n```\r\n\r\nAfter:\r\n```\r\nFAILED numpy/core/tests/test_umath.py::TestSpecialFloats::test_tan - AssertionError: FloatingPointError not raised by tan\r\n1 failed, 14766 passed, 204 skipped, 1268 deselected, 34 xfailed in 70.37s (0:01:10)\r\n```\r\n\r\n* Enhancement on top of workaround for clang bug in reciprocal\r\n\r\nEnhancement on top of workaround for clang bug in reciprocal (numpy/numpy#18555)\r\nNumpy's FP unary loops use a partial load / store on every iteration. The partial load / store helpers each insert a switch statement to know how many elements to handle. This causes a lot of unnecessary branches to be inserted in the loops. The partial load / store is only needed on the final iteration of the loop if it isn't a full vector.\r\n\r\nThe changes here breakout the final iteration to use the partial load / stores. The loop has been changed to use full load / stores. Additionally, this means we don't need to conditionalize the volatile workaround in the loop.\r\n\r\n* Address Azure CI failures with older versions of clang\r\n\r\n- -ftrapping-math is default enabled for Numpy, but support in clang is mainly for x86_64\r\n- Apple Clang and Clang have different, but overlapping versions\r\n- Non-Apple Clang versions come from looking at when they started supporting -ftrapping-math for x86_64\r\n\r\nTesting was done against Apple Clang versions\r\n- v11 / x86_64 - failed previously, now passes (azure failure)\r\n- v12+ / x86_64 - passes before and after\r\n- v13 / arm64 - failed before initial patch, passes after\r\n\r\n<!--         ----------------------------------------------------------------\r\n                MAKE SURE YOUR PR GETS THE ATTENTION IT DESERVES!\r\n                ----------------------------------------------------------------\r\n\r\n*  FORMAT IT RIGHT:\r\n      http://www.numpy.org/devdocs/dev/development_workflow.html#writing-the-commit-message\r\n\r\n*  IF IT'S A NEW FEATURE OR API CHANGE, TEST THE WATERS:\r\n      http://www.numpy.org/devdocs/dev/development_workflow.html#get-the-mailing-list-s-opinion\r\n\r\n*  HIT ALL THE GUIDELINES:\r\n      https://numpy.org/devdocs/dev/index.html#guidelines\r\n\r\n*  WHAT TO DO IF WE HAVEN'T GOTTEN BACK TO YOU:\r\n      http://www.numpy.org/devdocs/dev/development_workflow.html#getting-your-pr-reviewed\r\n-->\r\n",
    "user": {
        "id": 77272,
        "url": "https://api.github.com/users/charris",
        "type": "User",
        "login": "charris",
        "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjc3Mjcy",
        "html_url": "https://github.com/charris",
        "gists_url": "https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}",
        "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos",
        "avatar_url": "https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=4",
        "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}",
        "site_admin": false,
        "gravatar_id": "",
        "starred_url": "https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}",
        "followers_url": "https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers",
        "following_url": "https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}",

        "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions",
        "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events"
    },

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "* Resolve divide by zero in reciprocal #18555

clang has an optimization bug where a vector that is only partially loaded / stored will get narrowed to only the lanes used, which can be fine in some cases. However, in numpy's `reciprocal` function a partial load is explicitly extended to the full width of the register (filled with '1's) to avoid divide-by-zero. clang's optimization ignores the explicit filling with '1's.

The changes here insert a dummy `volatile` variable. This convinces clang not to narrow the load and ignore the explicit filling of '1's.

`volatile` can be expensive since it forces loads / stores to refresh contents whenever the variable is used. numpy has its own template / macro system that'll expand the loop function below for sqrt, absolute, square, and reciprocal. Additionally, the loop can be called on a full array if there's overlap between src and dst. Consequently, we try to limit the scope that we need to apply `volatile`. Intention is it should only be needed when compiling with clang, against Apple arm64, and only for the `reciprocal` function. Moreover, `volatile` is only needed when a vector is partially loaded.

Testing:
Beyond fixing the cases mentioned in the GitHub issue, the changes here also resolve several failures in numpy's test suite.

Before:
```
FAILED numpy/core/tests/test_scalarmath.py::TestBaseMath::test_blocked - RuntimeWarning: divide by zero encountered in reciprocal
FAILED numpy/core/tests/test_ufunc.py::TestUfuncGenericLoops::test_unary_PyUFunc_O_O_method_full[reciprocal] - AssertionError: FloatingPointError not raised
FAILED numpy/core/tests/test_umath.py::TestPower::test_power_float - RuntimeWarning: divide by zero encountered in reciprocal
FAILED numpy/core/tests/test_umath.py::TestSpecialFloats::test_tan - AssertionError: FloatingPointError not raised by tan
FAILED numpy/core/tests/test_umath.py::TestAVXUfuncs::test_avx_based_ufunc - RuntimeWarning: divide by zero encountered in reciprocal
FAILED numpy/linalg/tests/test_linalg.py::TestNormDouble::test_axis - RuntimeWarning: divide by zero encountered in reciprocal
FAILED numpy/linalg/tests/test_linalg.py::TestNormSingle::test_axis - RuntimeWarning: divide by zero encountered in reciprocal
FAILED numpy/linalg/tests/test_linalg.py::TestNormInt64::test_axis - RuntimeWarning: divide by zero encountered in reciprocal
8 failed, 14759 passed, 204 skipped, 1268 deselected, 34 xfailed in 69.90s (0:01:09)
```

After:
```
FAILED numpy/core/tests/test_umath.py::TestSpecialFloats::test_tan - AssertionError: FloatingPointError not raised by tan
1 failed, 14766 passed, 204 skipped, 1268 deselected, 34 xfailed in 70.37s (0:01:10)
```

* Enhancement on top of workaround for clang bug in reciprocal

Enhancement on top of workaround for clang bug in reciprocal (numpy/numpy#18555)
Numpy's FP unary loops use a partial load / store on every iteration. The partial load / store helpers each insert a switch statement to know how many elements to handle. This causes a lot of unnecessary branches to be inserted in the loops. The partial load / store is only needed on the final iteration of the loop if it isn't a full vector.

The changes here breakout the final iteration to use the partial load / stores. The loop has been changed to use full load / stores. Additionally, this means we don't need to conditionalize the volatile workaround in the loop.

* Address Azure CI failures with older versions of clang

- -ftrapping-math is default enabled for Numpy, but support in clang is mainly for x86_64
- Apple Clang and Clang have different, but overlapping versions
- Non-Apple Clang versions come from looking at when they started supporting -ftrapping-math for x86_64

Testing was done against Apple Clang versions
- v11 / x86_64 - failed previously, now passes (azure failure)
- v12+ / x86_64 - passes before and after
- v13 / arm64 - failed before initial patch, passes after

<!--         ----------------------------------------------------------------
                MAKE SURE YOUR PR GETS THE ATTENTION IT DESERVES!
                ----------------------------------------------------------------

*  FORMAT IT RIGHT:
      http://www.numpy.org/devdocs/dev/development_workflow.html#writing-the-commit-message

*  IF IT'S A NEW FEATURE OR API CHANGE, TEST THE WATERS:
      http://www.numpy.org/devdocs/dev/development_workflow.html#get-the-mailing-list-s-opinion

*  HIT ALL THE GUIDELINES:
      https://numpy.org/devdocs/dev/index.html#guidelines

*  WHAT TO DO IF WE HAVEN'T GOTTEN BACK TO YOU:
      http://www.numpy.org/devdocs/dev/development_workflow.html#getting-your-pr-reviewed
-->
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "BUG: Resolve Divide by Zero on Apple silicon + test failures (#19926)"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "00 - Bug",
            "description": null
        },
        {
            "name": "08 - Backport",
            "description": ""
        },
        {
            "name": "component: SIMD",
            "description": "Issues in SIMD (fast instruction sets) code or machinery."
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}
